metadata.case_name: State of Uttar Pradesh v. Indian Sugar Millers Association

facts.text: Indian National Sugar Mills Workers Federation served notices on various sugar factories in Uttar Pradesh on December 15, 1949, demanding bonus for 1948-49 and restoration of reduction in previous years' bonus, threatening strike from January 16, 1950.
Government of Uttar Pradesh appointed Court of Inquiry under ss. 6 and 10 of Industrial Disputes Act, 1947, and referred dispute to it; notification amended twice.
Court of Inquiry held full enquiry with representations from employers and employees, submitted report on April 15, 1950.
Government published Court of Inquiry report in Uttar Pradesh Gazette on May 8, 1950, as per s.17 Industrial Disputes Act, 1947.

On July 5, 1950, Government under s.3(b) U.P. Industrial Disputes Act, 1947, issued notification directing sugar factories to pay bonus for 1947-48 and 1948-49, and retaining allowances to skilled seasonal workmen and clerical staff from off-season 1950.
Indian Sugar Millers Association filed writ petition under Art.226 Constitution before Allahabad High Court on September 14, 1950; dismissed for lack of legal interest.
Various sugar mills, including respondents, filed separate writ petitions before Allahabad High Court raising fourteen grounds.
Allahabad High Court Full Bench allowed writ petitions on bonus payment issue; Sapru J. expressed doubt on invalidity of government order.
State of Uttar Pradesh obtained certificate under Art.133(1)(b) and (c) Constitution and appealed to Supreme Court.

legal_issues.text: Whether clause (b) of s.3 U.P. Industrial Disputes Act, 1947 operates retrospectively to direct payment of bonus for past years 1947-48 and 1948-49.
Whether clause (b) of s.3 applies where an industrial dispute has arisen, or only clause (d) is appropriate.
Whether clause (b) of s.3 is ultra vires Art.14 (discrimination) and Art.19(1)(g) (unreasonable restriction on trade) of Constitution if applicable to industrial disputes.

petitioner_arguments.text: Provisions of clause (b) s.3 are wide enough to direct payment of bonus for past years as it imposes a condition of employment in future.
Direction to pay bonus attaches condition to employment in 1950-51, not retrospective; bonus payable only to workers who worked in relevant past years.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Minimum Wages Act (example of statutory wage condition)

petitioner_arguments.text: Clause (b) applicable in emergency for public safety/convenience/maintenance of supplies/employment; temporary measure, not circumventing judicial process under cl.(d).
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: s.3 U.P. Industrial Disputes Act, 1947; Art.19(6) Constitution

respondent_arguments.text: Clause (b) s.3 is prospective only, cannot require payment of bonus for past employment periods.
Where industrial dispute exists, must use cl.(d) for conciliation/adjudication, not executive order under general cl.(b).
Clause (b) enables arbitrary discrimination between industries/workers (Art.14) and unreasonable restrictions on business (Art.19(1)(g)).
Bonus is contractual like wages, cannot be imposed as future condition for past work; would apply to new employees contrary to bonus concept.

court_reasoning.text: Agrees clause (b) not retrospective, but government order attaches bonus payment as condition to future employment in 1950-51, payable only to past workers; not retrospective effect.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Payment directed within six weeks of order, augmenting past wages as future employment condition.

court_reasoning.text: Bonus can be made statutory condition of employment like minimum wages; s.3 empowers imposing terms/conditions regardless of contractual origin.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Legislature did not import contractual sense into 'term or condition of employment'.

court_reasoning.text: Cl.(b) for emergencies (public safety etc.), temporary/interim orders; normal way is judicial under cl.(d), but cl.(b) supplements in acute urgency; no refusal to refer under cl.(d) post cl.(b).
court_reasoning.key_observation: Subjective satisfaction of government; can be compelled by mandamus.

court_reasoning.text: No discrimination (Art.14) as limited to emergency/public interest; temporary restriction reasonable under Art.19(6).

holdings.text: Cl.(b) s.3 U.P. Industrial Disputes Act, 1947 not retrospective but permits directing past bonus as future employment condition.
Cl.(b) applicable in emergency as temporary measure alongside cl.(d); not alternative but supplementary.
Cl.(b) not ultra vires Arts.14, 19(1)(g) when limited to emergency/public interest.

precedents_cited.case_name: L. D. Sugar Mills v. U. P. Government
precedents_cited.relevance: Single judge view on cl.(b) prospective and not for past disputes; observations quoted by respondent.

precedents_cited.case_name: Ram Nath Koeri v. Lakshmi Devi Sugar Mills
precedents_cited.relevance: Division Bench reversed Bhargava J., supporting use of cl.(b) for varying terms.

statutes_cited.name: U.P. Industrial Disputes Act, 1947
statutes_cited.relevance: Empowers government orders in emergency for terms/conditions of employment, conciliation/adjudication; cl.(b) temporary.

statutes_cited.name: Industrial Disputes Act, 1947
statutes_cited.relevance: Appointment of Court of Inquiry, reference of dispute, publication of report.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Writ jurisdiction, appeal certificate, equality, trade freedom/reasonable restrictions, abrogation of inconsistent laws.

statutes_cited.name: Minimum Wages Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Example of statutory imposition of wage as employment condition.

outcome.summary: Appeal allowed; High Court writ quashing government bonus order set aside; government order under s.3(b) upheld as valid.
outcome.relief_granted: Restoration of government notification directing bonus payment.

key_quotes.text: By giving this direction the State Government did nothing more than attach a condition to the employment of workmen in the year 1950-51 in sugar factories affected by the order.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: Clause b of s. 3 was apparently enacted for this purpose. An order made thereunder would be in the nature of a temporary or interim order.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Limits cl.(b) to emergencies, distinguishing from cl.(d).

key_quotes.text: The employees might well have taken in the industrial dispute the line that the payment of bonus in respect of the years 1947-48 and 1948-49 to the workmen employed in those years was regarded by those who were employed in future as a preliminary and essential condition.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Sapru J. observation adopted; links past dispute to future contentment.
